Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Functional response and predator prey interactions between cheetahs and gazelles
Award.AbstractNarration:
Predation is one of the most important controls on the abundance of wildlife. Key to understanding how predators regulate the abundance of their prey and maintain their own numbers is knowing how predators change their behavior according to the prey they encounter. For example, predators might largely ignore rare types of prey and so help conserve them, simply consume all types of prey in proportion to their abundance, or reach an upper limit of consumption of very abundant prey, leaving them relatively free to multiply and dominate further. This project will refine our understanding of how predators respond to the abundance of prey by asking how responses differ between male and female predators and how threats from larger predators may change the behavior of smaller ones. In most cases, these questions are nearly impossible to answer directly because it is too hard to observe individual hunts in the wild, or because humans have exterminated predators. This project will take advance of a case where the researchers have developed methods to follow wild hunts in a largely intact system, predation by cheetahs on gazelles in the African savanna. The results of this project will expand the scientific basis for wildlife management in Africa and North America, improve conservation through outreach to the public, strengthen international collaboration, and train a U.S. Ph.D. student.

Functional responses of predators determine how the abundances of both predators and prey increase and decrease in nature. This project will deepen our understanding of rates and efficiencies of predation in nature by studying differences within a species of predator, in particular the potential for different responses in males and females to the density of prey that they encounter and to threats from larger predators as they hunt. The project will take advantage of a system where it is possible to follow individual predators in a habitat where large populations of wildlife still remain, cheetahs preying on gazelles in the savanna of Serengeti National Park in Tanzania. Researchers will watch hunts by individual cheetahs for several days each and combine these observations with historical data to discover how age of cheetahs, social grouping of cheetahs and gazelles, and threats from lions determine the rates at which female and male cheetahs kill prey. The project will use social media to educate the public about cheetahs, which are listed as a vulnerable species on the IUCN Red List. Researchers will deliver talks on conservation of wildlife to tour groups, safari drivers, and college students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carnivores are built to be effective predators.  They have claws and teeth, and they must be strong and fast to take down their prey.  However, they often turn these abilities against others, harassing, stealing prey from and occasionally killing smaller carnivores.  Yet ecosystems with multiple carnivore species can exist because smaller carnivores have strategies to deal with the risks they face from the larger ones.  Many of these strategies require enough space for the smaller carnivores to move around and so avoid encounters with larger ones.  But when smaller carnivores are hunting and eating their prey, they are unable to move without losing the kill. At the same time, kills attract other carnivores looking for an easy meal.  Thus, feeding is a potentially vulnerable time for smaller carnivores and they need to use other behaviors to minimize the risk of their kill being stolen.

We studied cheetahs in Serengeti National Park in Tanzania to discover how they modify their hunting and eating behaviors to deal with risks from lions and hyenas who pose a lethal threat to cheetah cubs and occasionally even adults.  Moreover, lions and hyenas steal roughly ten percent of cheetahs’ kills.

We found that cheetahs do indeed alter their feeding behavior to minimize their risk of encountering larger carnivores, and that these alterations depend on their social groupings.  Males, single females, and adolescent cheetahs more often opt for the ‘eat fast and get out’ strategy.  Mothers with cubs must juggle a few more considerations including their cubs’ safety, making sure that the cubs get enough to eat and at the same time learn the hunting skills essential for future survival.  Thus, mothers with cubs have to spend more time on kills but lower the risk by being vigilant.  My research highlights the behaviors that smaller carnivores use to coexist with larger predators.  Understanding how large carnivores can affect the feeding behavior of smaller ones helps us unravel the complex relationships between predators and how that can potentially affect prey species.

Broader Impacts

While doing my fieldwork in Serengeti, I used social media extensively to talk about daily life in the field and cheetah ecology, behavior and conservation.  I could use Twitter while watching cheetahs and live tweet their behavior.  Through an extensive use of pictures and commentary I could bring to life both my research and the nitty gritty of the lives of carnivores, including the gory details that are mostly absent from nature documentaries.  With visuals, humor, and by condensing complex scientific information into short accessible bullet points, I talked about cheetahs and my research to thousands of Twitter followers.  Through the Facebook page of the Serengeti Cheetah Project (SCP) I provided lengthier updates on the cheetahs in our study area.  I also disseminated a newsletter about my fieldwork to donors and later turned these into blog posts on my website.  I trained a Tanzanian scientist to take over as project manager for SCP.  Additionally, I gave talks on cheetah ecology and conservation to Tanzanian and American high school students, university students from the UK, and local organizations in Blacksburg, VA.
